# Banking System Stability

Despite increasing uncertainties in the global economy and financial markets, Hong Kong's banking system remained resilient in 2018. The effectiveness of liquidity and credit risk management frameworks of authorized institutions continued to be a key regulatory focus for the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) throughout the year. Given the persistent rise in cyber threats and the broader adoption of fintech in the banking sector, the HKMA enhanced its regulatory oversight of authorized institutions' technological risk management and business continuity capabilities. In May, the HKMA issued a revised guideline titled "Authorization of Virtual Banks" and began processing applications for virtual bank authorizations. In terms of conduct regulation, the HKMA implemented further measures to strengthen oversight of the sales practices of investment and insurance products by authorized institutions, promote accessible banking services for persons with disabilities, and advocate a customer-centric corporate culture.

As financial crimes become increasingly complex and globalized, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to leverage new technologies and a risk-based approach to enhance Hong Kong's capacity to respond to money laundering and terrorist financing. The HKMA has made satisfactory progress in implementing international regulatory standards, including capital adequacy standards, disclosure standards, liquidity standards, and limits on large risk exposures. Additionally, the HKMA has strengthened communication with the banking sector to ensure an appropriate balance between regulatory effectiveness and market development.

Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to work to ensure Hong Kong has a credible mechanism for handling authorized institutions, including introducing rules on minimum loss-absorbing capacity to address a major obstacle facing the feasibility of handling such institutions.

# Goal

One of the HKMA's overall objectives is to promote the safety and stability of the banking system. Achieving this goal relies on establishing and maintaining a highly resilient financial system capable of providing the critical financial services required by Hong Kong's economy.

Banks may affect the stability of the banking system through their operational practices, or even through disorderly closures in extreme cases. As a regulatory authority, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) plays a crucial role in safeguarding financial stability, ensuring that banks have the capacity to withstand shocks, respond to crises, and recover from them to return to normal operations, ultimately helping to prevent bank failures. The HKMA is responsible for prudential regulation of banks, as well as the authorization of licensed banks, restricted licensed banks, and deposit-taking companies in Hong Kong (collectively referred to as "authorized institutions"). The HKMA also oversees the designation and regulation of certain financial market infrastructures.

However, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) cannot guarantee that the financial system is entirely risk-free, and Hong Kong's prudential regulatory regime is not designed to ensure "zero risk." As one of the resolution authorities, the HKMA strives to ensure that if an authorized institution becomes unsustainable, its failure can be handled in an orderly manner. To this end, Hong Kong has established a financial institution resolution mechanism, under which the HKMA serves as the resolution authority for certain financial institutions, including authorized institutions. To build an efficient Hong Kong resolution mechanism, it is necessary to establish resolution legislation and policy standards, conduct resolution planning to remove obstacles to the feasibility of resolving authorized institutions, and develop the HKMA's operational capacity to resolve insolvent authorized institutions. To effectively carry out the aforementioned tasks, the HKMA needs to adopt internationally consistent and coordinated approaches.

# 2018 Year in Review

# Regulatory Oversight Overview

In 2018, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) conducted a total of 187 off-site reviews, covering a wide range of areas including the CAMEL ratings of authorized institutions, corporate governance, business operations and risk management, as well as the business strategies of authorized institutions in response to the development of financial technology. To continue enhancing the risk governance standards of authorized institutions, the HKMA held 27 meetings with the boards of directors or their committees of authorized institutions, and monitored the progress of authorized institutions in implementing corporate governance guidelines. In addition, the HKMA held 28 trilateral meetings with authorized institutions and their external auditors.

In addition to off-site review work, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to conduct regular on-site inspections, complemented by thematic assessments to examine areas assessed as higher risk. Throughout the year, the HKMA carried out a total of 392 on-site inspections and thematic assessments, continuing to focus primarily on credit risk management. Other key areas of emphasis include technology risk and operational risk management, as well as anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing measures. The HKMA has also increased the frequency of on-site inspections and thematic assessments related to liquidity and market risk management, as well as the implementation of the Basel capital adequacy framework. Specialized inspection teams also conducted on-site inspections of authorized institutions' securities, investment products, insurance, and Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF)-related businesses.

Table 1 contains a summary of the HKMA's regulatory activities in 2018.

# Credit Risk Regulation

# Credit Growth and Asset Quality

Credit growth slowed in 2018, with total loans increasing by 4.4% for the year, compared to a 16.1% increase in 2017 (Table 2). Trade financing decreased by 7.6% in 2018. The slowdown in loan growth was primarily due to the increasingly uncertain global economic and trade environment, leading to a contraction in credit demand.

Table 2: Growth of Loans and Advances

The total related loans in the mainland increased by 1.4% to 4.249 trillion Hong Kong dollars by the end of 2018, lower than the 2017 growth rate (Table 3).

Table 3: Related Loan Growth in the Mainland

The asset quality of recognized institutions remained robust in 2018. The specific category loan ratio for retail banks decreased from 0.56% at the end of 2017 to 0.50% at the end of 2018, far below the long-term average of 2.1% since 2000; during the same period, the specific category loan ratio for the overall banking sector fell from 0.68% to 0.55%. For mainland-related loans, the specific category loan ratio for retail banks decreased from 0.75% to 0.63% in 2018, while the overall banking sector's related ratio also fell from 0.67% a year earlier to 0.54%.

Within the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) strengthened its regulatory oversight to ensure that authorized institutions continued to adhere to prudent credit risk management guidelines. In particular, the HKMA proactively investigated the background and structure of large enterprises to enhance its monitoring system for corporate credit risk. Additionally, the HKMA conducted thematic assessments focusing on key credit risk management measures, such as the criteria for approving large enterprise loans and risk management practices, loan classification and provisioning systems, credit risk governance frameworks, risk management of real estate developer loans, secured loans, and policy loans.

# Real Estate Mortgage Loan

Residential property prices reached a historical high in July 2018 but showed signs of easing in the second half of the year. The eight rounds of countercyclical macroprudential regulatory measures introduced by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) since October 2009 have enhanced the resilience of Hong Kong's banking system against a potential reversal in the local property market. The average loan-to-value ratio for new residential mortgages fell from 64% before the HKMA introduced its first round of countercyclical measures in September 2009 to 46% by December 2018. The average debt-to-income ratio also decreased from 41% when the HKMA first introduced the ratio cap in August 2010 to 34% by December 2018 (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Average Loan-to-Value Ratio and Mortgage Payment-to-Income Ratio for New Residential Mortgage Loans

# Regulation of Business Operations and Technology Risks

The technology risks faced by the banking sector remain high. In 2016, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) introduced the "Cyber Defense Assessment Framework." The first phase of implementation covered 30 authorized institutions, including all major banks, which have completed three stages of assessment: self-assessment of risk levels, maturity assessment, and (where applicable) risk-informed cyber attack simulation testing. These assessments help authorized institutions identify areas requiring improvement and implement corrective measures to enhance their cyber defenses. Meanwhile, the HKMA has established a timetable for the implementation of the second and third phases, which will cover the remaining authorized institutions. This year, the HKMA will conduct on-site reviews, focusing on the cybersecurity controls, outsourcing arrangements, and information technology governance of authorized institutions.

# SmartBank

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to collaborate with the banking sector on seven measures promoting smart banking, which were announced in September 2017, to foster the development of financial technology in Hong Kong. In terms of regulation, the HKMA issued a revised version of the "Recognition of Virtual Banks" guidelines in May. Additionally, under the "Banking Easy" initiative, the HKMA has streamlined regulatory requirements related to remote account opening, online lending, and online wealth management. These optimized regulatory requirements help banks provide a better online banking user experience. In September, the scope of the "Banking Easy" initiative was expanded to promote banks' adoption of financial compliance technology (RegTech), with three new areas of focus including monitoring technology to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, financial compliance technology used for prudent risk management and compliance, and machine-readable regulatory requirements.

Mr. Wong Kwok Hang, Deputy Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, delivered a speech titled "Financial Compliance Technology in the New Era of Smart Banking" at the "Hong Kong Bankers' Summit 2018", which was organized by the Hong Kong Banking Society.

# Regulation of Liquidity and Market Risks

With the ongoing normalization of U.S. monetary policy, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has strengthened its regulation of liquidity risk to ensure authorized institutions prudently and effectively manage their liquidity risks. During the year, the HKMA conducted a round of thematic assessments to evaluate the preparedness of authorized institutions for potential tightening of USD liquidity and their capacity for internal liquidity stress testing. Additionally, the HKMA is monitoring the compliance of authorized institutions with the "net stable funding ratio" requirements that took effect in January.

In addition to reviewing the market risk management of authorized institutions' bond portfolios, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority conducted a specialized on-site review focusing on the Global Foreign Exchange Code and margin and risk mitigation standards for non-central counterparty over-the-counter derivatives, to examine the extent to which authorized institutions are complying with new international standards in their treasury operations.

# Combat Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing

The government's April-issued "Hong Kong Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Risk Assessment Report" noted that Hong Kong's banking system faces significant money laundering threats, similar to other international financial centers, reflecting the increasing globalization and complexity of financial services. The money laundering threats confronting Hong Kong stem not only from local criminal activities but to a greater extent from overseas activities. These overseas activities include illicit proceeds from corruption abroad, fraudulent activities by transnational criminal groups, tax evasion, and risks related to sanctions stemming from Hong Kong's role as a payment and trade hub. With the assistance of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the government formulated a policy statement on combating money laundering and terrorist financing, outlining responses to these threats, aiming to enhance the effectiveness of the anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing regime while also attracting and facilitating legitimate businesses.

The "Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism (Financial Institutions) (Amendment) Ordinance 2018" came into effect on March 1, introducing amendments that grant flexibility in verifying customer identities to align with the development of authorized institutions utilizing technology to facilitate customer account opening. The new legislation also expands its scope, requiring lawyers, accountants, real estate agents, and trust or company service providers to assume responsibilities in combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism, thereby comprehensively strengthening the system for combating money laundering and terrorist financing. These amendments, together with revisions to the Companies Ordinance aimed at enhancing transparency of beneficial ownership, assist authorized institutions in carrying out their duties related to anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing.

To consolidate and further strengthen communication with recognized institutions regarding policies and regulatory approaches for combating money laundering and terrorist financing, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) issued in October a new unit titled "Regulatory Approach to Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing" under the "Regulatory Policy Manual," alongside the revised "Guidelines on Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (Applicable to Recognized Institutions)" to support the more effective implementation of a risk-based approach and to reduce obstacles for recognized institutions in adopting new technologies under the AML and CTF framework.

The role of information sharing in combating money laundering and terrorist financing has become increasingly important. With the support of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Hong Kong Bankers Association (Banking Association), the banking sector has actively participated in the Anti-Fraud and Anti-Money Laundering Intelligence Working Group, achieving substantial results. The review of the pilot program for the Intelligence Working Group was launched in late 2018 and will be completed in early 2019.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位是金管局主要職責之一。旨在促進銀行及支付業界開發與應用金融科技的7項措施，於年內取得良好進展，最佳例子是快速支付系統「轉數快」成功推出。

中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃推出優化措施，以及粵港澳大灣區的發展，令香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位亦更為穩固，本港人民幣金融活動蓬勃發展。

與此同時，金管局致力開拓新機遇，進一步提升香港金融平台的競爭力，包括基建融資、企業財資中心及綠色債券市場。金管局亦加強向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港優勢的市場推廣計劃。在國際層面，金管局於多個區內及國際委員會扮演領導角色，明確體現了香港在相關國際工作的專業知識及承擔。

# 概覽

為加強香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位，金管局致力落實於2017年9月公布、旨在促進銀行及支付行業開發與應用金融科技的7項措施。該7項推動智慧銀行的措施於年內取得的主要進展包括：

- 成功推出快速支付系統「轉數快」，全面接通不同銀行及儲值支付工具（統稱「電子錢包」）
- 發布銀行業開放應用程式介面（開放API）框架及促進業界落實開放API；
- 提升金融科技研究及人才培訓；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；
- 修訂《虛擬銀行的認可》指引，並處理虛擬銀行牌照申請；
- 「金融科技監管沙盒」升級版（FSS 2.0）運作順暢；及
- 擴展「銀行易」以促進銀行採用金融合規科技。

金管局轄下金融科技促進辦公室(FFO)，聯同金管局各銀行部門在推動落實上述措施方面擔當重要角色。

隨着中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃優化措施的落實，香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。「債券通」全面實施即時貨銀兩訖(DvP)結算模式及國務院宣布境外投資者投資中國境內債券市場的稅務寛免安排，進一步提升計劃的效率及吸引力。金管局亦與內地當局緊密合作，探討及實施多項金融配套措施，便利在粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）生活、工作及營商的個人和企業。香港離岸人民幣業務繼續蓬勃發展，人民幣存款資金池全年上升6%至6,577億元人民幣；人民幣即時支付結算(RTGS)系統平均每日交易額達到10,101億元人民幣的高水平。

金管局積極開拓進一步提升香港金融平台競爭力的新機會。為促進香港債券市場的發展，金管局落實《財政預算案》所提出的「債券資助先導計劃」，為首次在香港發行債券的機構提供資助，並與政府緊密合作修訂法例，擴大「合資格債務票據計劃」下可獲稅務豁免的債券投資收入範圍。金管局亦加強市場推廣活動，向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港的優勢，包括舉辦多項大型及專題外展活動推廣香港為綠色金融、基建融資及企業財資中心樞紐。

在國際層面，金管局領導多個區內及國際委員會。金管局現正擔任金融穩定理事會轄下監管合作常設委員會主席、巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下監管及實施準則小組，以及東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP) 轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

香港金融基建的安全及有效運作，為香港作為國際金融中心的地位奠定穩固基礎。處理銀行同業交易的4個RTGS系統、債務工具中央結算系統（CMU系統）及香港交易資料儲存庫（香港儲存庫）在2018年達到100%的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。透過於內地兩個中央證券託管機構的帳戶，CMU系統繼續協助結算「債券通」北向通交易，以及替相關CMU系統成員持有內地債務證券。

為促進零售支付業的整體安全及效率，金管局於8月根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）指定多兩個零售支付系統，使其運作受到金管局監察。迄今受金管局監察的指定零售支付系統增至6個。金管局亦對16個儲值支付工具持牌人進行監管。有關持牌人積極推出新產品及服務，致力為客戶提供更多選擇及更佳的用戶體驗。與此同時，電子支票與電子帳單及繳費服務涵蓋範圍，進一步擴展至包括香港與整個廣東省的跨境支付交易。

# 2018年回顧

# 香港作為亞洲的金融科技樞紐

# 推動智慧銀行的措施

金管局於2017年9月公布7項推動智慧銀行的措施，旨在協助銀行業提升至更高層次，並把握銀行與科技結合帶來的龐大機遇。金管局於年內在落實這些措施及為香港金融生態轉型方面，進展良好。

# 「轉數快」

「轉數快」於9月成功啟動，方便銀行及儲值支付工具用戶隨時隨地進行港元及人民幣的跨行即時資金轉帳，用戶只需輸入收款人的手機號碼或電郵地址。共有21間銀行（包括大部分零售銀行）及10間儲值支付工具營運商已加入該系統，為客戶提供即時支付服務及╱或帳戶綁定服務。

「轉數快」在3.5個月內已接獲超過200萬個登記，相對香港人口比例27%。該系統自推出以來處理超過480萬宗交易，涉及總額逾1,049億港元及27.5億元人民幣。

金管局於同月推出香港零售支付共用二維碼標準及相關流動應用程式「香港共用二維碼」(HKQR)，是全球首創將多個二維碼整合成為個綜合二維碼的流動應用程式，方便商戶尤其中小企以同一個二維碼接受不同支付服務營運商的支付方案，無需向客戶展示多個二維碼。

# 開放應用程式介面

開放API是指透過向第三方服務供應商開放銀行的相關數據，更好更方便地融合銀行與其他行業的服務。用家單用一個系統就能在安全環境下享受綜合服務。為促進銀行界研發及提供開放API，金管局於7月發布開放API框架。該框架採用風險為本原則，並分4個階段落實各項開放API功能。截至2019年1月底，20間銀行已開放第一階段約500個開放API接口，涵蓋逾1,000項產品及服務的資料。

# 科研及人才培訓

建基於金管局主導的貿易融資概念驗證成果由香港多間銀行組成的聯盟於10月啟動以分布式分類帳技術(DLT)為基礎的貿易融資平台「貿易聯動」。該平台旨在透過數碼化貿易文件及自動化貿易融資流程，減低失誤及詐騙風險。截至2018年底，已有12間銀行加入成為該聯盟成員。「貿易聯動」與歐洲貿易融資平台「we.trade」於10月簽署《諒解備忘錄》，進行對接雙方平台的概念驗證。金管局亦同步探討「貿易聯動」與其他地區對接的機會，包括與新加坡金融管理局合作推出「全球貿易連接網絡」。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左）於「貿易聯動」啟動儀式上。

為培育更多金融科技專才，金管局於1月與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作推出「金融科技人才培育計劃」升級版(FCAS 2.0)。FCAS 2.0設有4個項目，適合處於不同職涯發展階段的年輕人才。計劃下有200多名學生受惠。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左二）與數碼港主席林家禮博士（左一）、香港應科院主席王明鑫先生（右二）及香港科技園公司行政總裁黃克強先生（右一）出席FCAS 2.0啟動儀式。

# 跨境合作

繼於2017年與深圳市人民政府金融發展服務辦公室（深圳金融辦）簽署《諒解備忘錄》後，金管局繼續加強與深圳的金融科技合作。當中包括金管局贊助「深圳金融科技暑期實習計劃」，讓50名學生到深圳多間著名公司進行為期6星期的實習，體驗當地的金融科技生態；另與深圳金融辦第二次合辦「深港金融科技創新獎」。

金管局副總裁李達志先生（右二）與首批深圳金融科技暑期實習生交談。

金管局亦於2018年與瑞士金融市場監督管理局、波蘭金融監管局、阿布扎比國際金融中心金融服務監管局及巴西中央銀行簽署金融科技合作協議，促進金融科技合作。

在8月，金管局與11間金融監管當局和相關機構公布「全球金融創新網絡」計劃。該網絡旨在為創新型公司提供更有效方式與監管機構進行互動，並促進監管機構之間就創新相關議題的合作。

# 虛擬銀行

引入虛擬銀行將會為香港金融科技應用增添新動力，並為數碼銀行客戶帶來嶄新體驗。虛擬銀行以個人或中小企等零售客戶為對象，因此亦有助促進普及金融。經公眾諮詢，金管局於5月發出《虛擬銀行的認可》指引修訂本，並於8月底接獲約30宗申請。

# 金融科技監管沙盒

年內沙盒的使用穩步上升。為協助建立金融合規科技的生態系統，沙盒於9月起開放予金融合規科技的項目。

截至2018年底，共有42項金融科技或科技產品獲准使用沙盒進行測試，其中28項已完成試行，有關產品亦已於其後推出市場。金管局另接獲220項使用「金融科技監管聊天室」的個案，希望在金融科技項目構思初期取得監管反饋意見。其中有約70%的個案來自科技公司。

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

Consolidating Hong Kong's status as an international financial center is one of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's primary responsibilities. The seven measures aimed at promoting the banking and payment sectors to develop and apply financial technology have made good progress this year, with the successful launch of the fast payment system "FPS (Turns Fast)" serving as the best example.

The optimization measures introduced for the connectivity program between mainland China's and Hong Kong's capital markets, along with the development of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, have further strengthened Hong Kong's unique position as the primary gateway to mainland China. Hong Kong's status as a global offshore RMB hub has also become more firmly established, with robust growth in RMB financial activities in the territory.

At the same time, the HKMA is committed to exploring new opportunities to further enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform, including infrastructure financing, corporate treasury centers, and the green bond market. The HKMA has also intensified its market promotion initiatives to communicate Hong Kong's strengths to overseas and mainland stakeholders. On the international stage, the HKMA plays a leading role in multiple regional and international committees, clearly demonstrating Hong Kong's expertise and commitment in relevant international endeavors.

# Overview

To strengthen Hong Kong's position as Asia's fintech hub, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to implementing seven measures announced in September 2017, aimed at promoting the development and application of fintech in the banking and payment sectors. The main progress made in the year regarding these seven measures promoting smart banking includes:

- Successfully launched the fast payment system "TransferFast," fully connecting different banks and stored value payment tools (collectively referred to as "electronic wallets");
- Released the open application programming interface (open API) framework for the banking industry and promoted the industry's implementation of open APIs;
- Enhanced fintech research and talent training;
- Strengthened cross-border fintech collaboration;
- Revised the guidelines on the recognition of virtual banks and processed applications for virtual bank licenses;
- The upgraded version of the "Fintech Regulatory Sandbox" (FSS 2.0) is operating smoothly; and
- Expanded "Banking Easy" to promote banks' adoption of financial compliance technology.

The Fintech Facilitation Office (FFO) under the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the HKMA's various banking departments, plays a significant role in promoting the implementation of the aforementioned measures.

With the implementation of optimized measures under the China-Hong Kong capital market interconnectivity plan, Hong Kong's unique position as the primary gateway to mainland China has been further reinforced. The full implementation of the real-time gross settlement (DvP) model for Bond Connect, along with the State Council's announcement of tax exemption arrangements for overseas investors in mainland China's bond market, has further enhanced the efficiency and appeal of the program. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has also closely collaborated with mainland authorities to explore and implement various financial support measures, facilitating individuals and businesses living, working, and operating in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (GBA). Hong Kong's offshore RMB business continues to thrive, with the RMB deposit pool rising by 6% year-on-year to RMB657.7 billion. The average daily transaction value of the RMB real-time gross settlement (RTGS) system reached a high level of RMB1,010.1 billion.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is proactively exploring new opportunities to further enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform. To promote the development of Hong Kong's bond market, the HKMA has implemented the "Bond Subsidy Pilot Scheme" proposed in the Budget, providing subsidies to institutions issuing bonds for the first time in Hong Kong. It has also worked closely with the government to revise legislation, expanding the scope of bond investment income eligible for tax exemptions under the "Eligible Debt Instruments Scheme." Additionally, the HKMA has intensified its market promotion activities, communicating Hong Kong's advantages to overseas and mainland stakeholders, including organizing numerous large-scale and thematic outreach events to promote Hong Kong as a hub for green finance, infrastructure financing, and corporate treasury centers.

On the international level, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) leads several regional and international committees. The HKMA currently serves as Chair of the Standing Committee on Regulatory Cooperation under the Financial Stability Board, the Regulatory and Implementation Guidelines Working Group under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (Basel Committee), and the Financial Markets Working Group under the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks Meeting (EMEAP).

The safe and efficient operation of Hong Kong's financial infrastructure provides a solid foundation for Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. In 2018, the four RTGS systems handling interbank transactions, the Central Maturity Unit (CMU) system for debt instruments, and the Hong Kong Trade Repository (Hong Kong Repository) achieved 100% system availability, exceeding the target level of 99.95%. Through accounts at two mainland central securities depositories, the CMU system continues to assist in settling Northbound Bond Connect transactions and holds mainland debt securities on behalf of relevant CMU system members.

To enhance the overall security and efficiency of the retail payment industry, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) designated two additional retail payment systems in August under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Payment Tools Ordinance (Payment Ordinance), bringing the total number of designated retail payment systems under HKMA supervision to six. The HKMA also oversees 16 licensees of stored value payment tools. These licensees are actively introducing new products and services to provide customers with more choices and a better user experience. Meanwhile, the scope of electronic cheques and e-billing and payment services has further expanded to include cross-border payment transactions between Hong Kong and the entire Guangdong Province.

# 2018 Year in Review

# Hong Kong as Asia's Fintech Hub

# Measures to Promote Smart Banking

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced seven measures to promote smart banking in September 2017, aiming to help the banking industry elevate itself to a higher level and seize the significant opportunities brought about by the integration of banking and technology. The HKMA has made good progress in implementing these measures and advancing the transformation of Hong Kong's financial ecosystem within the year.

# 'Fast Speed'

"TransferFast" was successfully launched in September, enabling bank and e-wallet users to perform inter-bank instant fund transfers in Hong Kong dollars and Chinese yuan anytime and anywhere, simply by entering the recipient's mobile phone number or email address. A total of 21 banks (including most retail banks) and 10 e-wallet operators have joined the system, offering customers real-time payment services and/or account binding services.

The "TransferFast" system has received over 2 million registrations within 3.5 months, accounting for 27% of Hong Kong's population. Since its launch, the system has processed over 4.8 million transactions, involving a total value exceeding HKD 104.9 billion and RMB 2.75 billion.

In the same month, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the Hong Kong Shared QR Code Standard and its related mobile application "HKQR," a globally pioneering mobile application that integrates multiple QR codes into a single comprehensive QR code. This enables merchants, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), to accept payment schemes from different payment service providers using a single QR code, without needing to display multiple QR codes to customers.

# Open Application Interface

An open API refers to the practice of providing relevant banking data to third-party service providers, enabling better and more convenient integration of banking services with those of other industries. Users can enjoy comprehensive services in a secure environment using just one system. To promote the development and provision of open APIs within the banking sector, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) released an Open API framework in July. The framework adopts a risk-based principle and implements various open API functionalities in four phases. As of January 31, 2019, 20 banks had opened approximately 500 open API interfaces in the first phase, covering data on over 1,000 products and services.

# Scientific Research and Talent Training

Based on the results of the trade finance proof-of-concept led by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), a consortium of multiple Hong Kong banks launched the trade finance platform "TradeLink" in October, which is built on distributed ledger technology (DLT). The platform aims to reduce errors and fraud risks by digitizing trade documents and automating trade finance processes. By the end of 2018, 12 banks had joined as members of the consortium. In October, "TradeLink" signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the European trade finance platform "we.trade" to conduct a proof-of-concept verification of interoperability between the two platforms. The HKMA is also simultaneously exploring opportunities for "TradeLink" to connect with other regions, including the launch of the "Global Trade Connectivity Network" in collaboration with the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

Mr. Chan Tak-lam, Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (left), at the launch ceremony of "Trade Linkage".

To foster more financial technology specialists, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) partnered with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) in January to launch an upgraded version of the "Financial Technology Talent Development Program," known as FCAS 2.0. FCAS 2.0 features four initiatives tailored for young professionals at different career stages. Over 200 students have benefited from the program.

Mr. Chan Tak-lam, Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) (second from the left), along with Dr. Lam Ka-lei, Chairman of Digital Harbour (first from the left), Mr. Wong Ming-hin, Chairman of the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) (second from the right), and Mr. Wong Hark-keung, CEO of the Hong Kong Science Park Company (first from the right), attended the launch ceremony of FCAS 2.0.

# Cross-border Collaboration

Following the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Shenzhen Municipal Government's Financial Development Service Office (Shenzhen Financial Office) in 2017, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has continued to strengthen its fintech collaboration with Shenzhen. This includes the HKMA's sponsorship of the "Shenzhen Fintech Summer Internship Program," which allowed 50 students to intern at multiple renowned companies in Shenzhen for six weeks, experiencing the local fintech ecosystem. Additionally, the HKMA co-hosted the "Shenzhen-Hong Kong Fintech Innovation Award" for the second time with the Shenzhen Financial Office.

Mr. Lee Tak-chee, Deputy Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (second from the right), chats with the first batch of Shenzhen fintech summer interns.

In 2018, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) also signed fintech cooperation agreements with the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority (FINMA), the Polish Financial Supervision Authority, the Abu Dhabi Global Market Financial Services Regulatory Authority (ADGM FSRA), and the Central Bank of Brazil to promote fintech cooperation.

In August, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced the "Global Financial Innovation Network" initiative in collaboration with 11 financial regulatory authorities and related institutions. The network aims to provide innovative companies with more effective ways to interact with regulators and promote cooperation among regulators on innovation-related issues.

# Virtual Bank

Introducing virtual banks will add new momentum to fintech applications in Hong Kong and bring innovative experiences to digital banking customers. Targeting retail clients such as individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises, virtual banks will also help promote inclusive finance. After public consultation, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) issued a revised version of the "Approval of Virtual Banks" guidelines in May and received approximately 30 applications by the end of August.

# FinTech Regulatory Sandbox

The use of the sandbox has steadily increased this year. To help establish an ecosystem for financial compliance technology, the sandbox has been open to such projects since September.

As of the end of 2018, a total of 42 fintech or technology products had been approved to use the sandbox for testing, of which 28 had completed the trial and the relevant products had subsequently been launched to the market. The HKMA also received 220 cases involving the use of the "Fintech Regulatory Chatroom," aiming to obtain regulatory feedback on fintech projects during their early conceptualization stages. Approximately 70% of these cases originated from technology companies.

# 儲備管理

2018年對投資者而言是困難的一年，投資環境備受多項風險因素困擾，包括美國利率持續正常化引發金融狀況收緊、主要經濟體之間的貿易摩擦升級，以及全球多處民粹主義抬頭及地緣政治風險加劇。環球股市普遍向下，美國國庫券收益率亦隨着美國聯邦儲備局4次加息而上升。在美息趨升下，美元轉強。部分新興市場面對國內嚴峻的政治及經濟壓力，其貨幣顯著下挫。儘管投資環境充滿挑戰，外匯基金在2018年仍錄得109億港元投資收入。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產配置中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一及未來基金與外匯基金附屬公司存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎部分的總和。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但主要以未來基金除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2018年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重約為50:50。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置，即投資基準反映的配置情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，對資產進行戰略性配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局於8月成立外匯基金投資辦公室，專責投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約72%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分的投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約28%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，以取得可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取市場心得與專業投資技術知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，突顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況。金管局已加強風險評估，以配合外匯基金越趨多元化的投資；另採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，以識別促成不同表現的成因，藉此評估如何充分利用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資。例如，金管局已採納證券及期貨事務監察委員會公布的《負責任的擁有權原則》。該套原則旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局已就環境、社會及管治因素制定內部指引，適用於外聘基金經理的甄選、委任及監察程序。獲委任負責主動式管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理，須在管理有關投資時遵守《負責任的擁有權原則》。整體而言，金管局已將環境、社會及管治因素納入投資及相關監察活動的內部程序。金管局會密切注視環境、社會及管治因素的相關標準的發展，並評估如何能夠將這些標準進一步融入投資程序。此外，為促進負責任投資的國際合作，金管局已成為非牟利組織FCLTGlobal的成員，該組織旨在推動長遠目標為本的業務及投資決定。

# Reserve Management

2018 proved to be a challenging year for investors, as the investment environment was plagued by multiple risk factors, including tighter financial conditions triggered by the ongoing normalization of U.S. interest rates, the escalation of trade tensions among major economies, and the rise of populism and heightened geopolitical risks in various parts of the world. Global stock markets broadly declined, and U.S. Treasury yields rose in line with the Federal Reserve's four rate hikes. As U.S. interest rates increased, the dollar strengthened. Some emerging markets faced severe domestic political and economic pressures, leading to significant currency depreciation. Despite the challenging investment environment, the Exchange Fund recorded an investment income of HKD 10.9 billion in 2018.

# Foreign Exchange Fund

Under the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to directly or indirectly influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar, and it may also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's monetary and financial systems, thereby maintaining Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is accountable to the Financial Secretary for the management and investment of the Exchange Fund, in accordance with the powers delegated and the terms of the delegated authority by the Financial Secretary.

# Management of Foreign Exchange Funds

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee sets the following investment objectives for the Foreign Exchange Fund:

(a) Protect capital;  
(b) Ensure that the overall monetary base is always fully supported by highly liquid U.S. dollar assets at all times;  
(c) Ensure that liquidity is sufficient to maintain monetary and financial stability; and  
(d) Subject to the above (a) through (c), strive to achieve investment returns to protect the fund's long-term purchasing power.

The aforementioned objectives comprehensively take into account the statutory purposes of the foreign exchange fund and have been reflected in the foreign exchange fund's portfolio structure and target asset allocation.

The foreign exchange fund is primarily divided into two main portfolios: the support portfolio and the investment portfolio. The support portfolio holds highly liquid U.S. dollar assets, providing full support for the currency base in accordance with the regulations of the currency authority system. The investment portfolio primarily invests in the bond and stock markets of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) member countries to safeguard the value of assets and their long-term purchasing power.

To better manage risks and enhance long-term returns, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has gradually and cautiously diversified part of the Exchange Fund's assets across a broader range of asset classes, including emerging market and mainland bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure), and real estate. Emerging market and mainland bonds and equities are held in the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held in the long-term growth portfolio. The market value cap of the long-term growth portfolio is set at one-third of the Exchange Fund's accumulated surplus, plus the portion of deposits held by the future fund and the Exchange Fund's subsidiaries that is linked to the long-term growth portfolio.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares in Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, which were purchased by the government for strategic purposes under the Exchange Fund's account. Due to its unique nature, the investment performance evaluation of the Exchange Fund does not include this portfolio.

# Deposits in the Foreign Exchange Fund

The foreign exchange fund occasionally accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations, with interest rates generally linked to the performance of the investment portfolio, except for the Future Fund. The interest rate for deposits in the Future Fund is linked to the performance of both the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual interest rate depending on the proportion of each portfolio. As of the end of 2018, the Future Fund's allocation between the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio was approximately 50:50.

# Investment Process

The investment process of the Exchange Fund is based on strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation, which reflects the configuration indicated by the investment benchmark, shows the long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund can make to achieve its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses strategic allocation as a guide to conduct tactical asset allocation in an effort to achieve returns that exceed the benchmark. As a result, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark configuration (i.e., the strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual and benchmark configurations is referred to as "tactical deviation." The Financial Secretary sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limits after consulting the Exchange Fund Consultative Committee, while the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is authorized to determine the tactical asset allocation and set the permissible range for tactical deviation. Portfolio managers can select positions within the permissible range of tactical deviation to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Exchange Fund Investment Office in August, dedicated to investment and related risk management functions. The office's staff are responsible for directly managing approximately 72% of the Exchange Fund's investments, including the entire support portfolio and a portion of the investment portfolio. This portion is invested in global fixed-income markets and executes the Exchange Fund's macro risk management strategies through derivatives.

# External Investment Manager

In addition to managing assets through its internal staff, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) also employs external investment managers to oversee approximately 28% of the Exchange Fund's assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of engaging external investment managers is to leverage the best professional investment expertise available in the market to achieve sustainable returns for the Exchange Fund, enabling it to benefit from diversified and complementary investment strategies, as well as to gain insights into market practices and professional investment knowledge.

The expenses related to hiring external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction fees, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses are primarily influenced by market factors and vary from year to year.

# Risk Management and Oversight

The investment environment is becoming increasingly complex, highlighting the importance of risk management. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for investment portfolios managed by both internal and external investment managers, and closely monitors compliance with these guidelines and regulations. The HKMA has enhanced its risk assessment to align with the increasingly diversified investments of the Exchange Fund; additionally, it employs risk control tools to assess market risks under both normal and extremely adverse market conditions. The HKMA also conducts detailed analysis of investment performance factors to identify the causes behind different performance outcomes, thereby assessing how to fully leverage the investment management capabilities of internal and external investment managers.

# Responsible Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) supports responsible investment. For example, the HKMA has adopted the "Principles of Responsible Ownership" published by the Securities and Futures Commission. These principles aim to help investors determine how best to fulfill their ownership responsibilities in relation to investments in Hong Kong-listed companies. In terms of managing the Exchange Fund, the HKMA has established internal guidelines on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, which apply to the selection, appointment, and monitoring processes of external fund managers. External fund managers appointed to actively manage Hong Kong equity portfolios must adhere to the Principles of Responsible Ownership when managing these investments. Overall, the HKMA has incorporated ESG factors into its internal procedures for investment and related monitoring activities. The HKMA will closely monitor the development of relevant ESG standards and assess how these standards can be further integrated into investment processes. In addition, to promote international cooperation on responsible investment, the HKMA has become a member of the non-profit organization FCLT Global, which aims to promote business and investment decisions oriented toward long-term goals.

# Performance of the Foreign Exchange Fund

# 2018 Financial Market

In 2018, multiple risk factors that had been previously underestimated by the market surfaced sequentially, including the pace of U.S. interest rate normalization, the impact of the U.S. government's foreign trade policy and protectionism on global trade, as well as geopolitical risks, leading to significant fluctuations and adjustments in global financial markets.

The escalation of the US-China trade dispute has caused significant concern among investors, leading emerging market and Hong Kong stocks to fluctuate downward since early January. The Hang Seng Index has fallen as much as 27% from its peak in that month. Starting from the fourth quarter, major European and American stock markets also experienced sharp declines, recording double-digit percentage drops. Overall in 2018, global stock markets generally declined, with the MSCI World Index, which covers developed market stocks, falling 10.4%, and the MSCI Emerging Markets Index also dropping 16.6%.

In the bond market, U.S. Treasury yields generally rose in 2018 due to the normalization of U.S. monetary policy. However, the bond market remained volatile throughout the year. For example, the 10-year U.S. Treasury yield rose from around 2.5% at the start of the year to a 7-year high of 3.2% in November, but by year-end it softened to 2.7% due to investor concerns over Sino-U.S. trade tensions and a shift toward risk-averse investments.

In the currency market, the US dollar strengthened this year following US interest rate hikes. The US Dollar Index rose 4.4%, while major currencies such as the euro and the Chinese yuan fell approximately 5% against the dollar. Additionally, some emerging markets experienced further currency depreciation due to domestic political instability and economic uncertainty. For example, the Argentine peso and Turkish lira fell by approximately 50% and 30% against the US dollar, respectively. In contrast, safe-haven investment demand pushed the Japanese yen up 2.7% against the US dollar.

# 金管局員工

金管局是政府架構的一部分，但按非公務員條款聘請員工，吸引具適當經驗及專門知識的人才。作為公營機構，金管局不斷精簡工作流程，提高效率及成本效益。金管局致力維持精簡靈活的組織架構，並盡可能透過調配現有人手推行新措施及應付不斷增加的工作量。

金管局是提供平等就業機會的僱主，並確保員工能夠在沒有歧視的環境下工作。金管局的平等機會政策適用於聘用、薪酬與福利、表現評核、晉升、調職╱培訓機會及一般行為操守等方面。

金管局聘用、培訓及維持一支專業優秀的工作團隊，以履行政策目標及靈活應對工作要求的轉變。金管局要求其員工維持高水平的操守及道德標準，不論何時都恪守極高的個人行為及操守規範，並以金管局的最佳利益為依歸。

財政司司長每年檢討金管局員工薪酬時，會透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的建議，並考慮管治委員會對金管局過去一年的表現評估、獨立人力資源顧問公司進行的金融業薪酬調查結果，以及其他相關因素。個別工作表現優秀的員工的薪酬亦可能獲得特別調整，以保持其薪酬競爭力。

金管局按個別員工的工作表現，分配獲批准用作調整年度固定薪酬及浮動薪酬的款項；而適用於負責投資的員工的浮動薪酬制度，則旨在加強其投資表現與薪酬的連繫。助理總裁及以上職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，是由財政司司長經參考管治委員會的意見後批准，有關員工在會議討論到其薪酬的議案時會避席。主管及以下職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，則由金管局總裁根據財政司司長授權，並按照獲批准用作支付薪酬的整筆款項來決定。

# Institutional Functions

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains effective communication with society and the market through various channels, including media, websites, public education initiatives, and other means, to enhance public understanding of its policies and operations. Throughout the year, the HKMA continued to strengthen institutional governance, including supporting employees in enhancing their professional capabilities, maintaining strict financial controls, and enhancing information technology security, to address the challenges arising from implementing new measures and the increasing workload.

# Maintain Contact with the Public

# Media Relations and Social Media

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains close communication with the media to enhance transparency and improve public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2018, the Authority held a total of 96 public media events, including 21 press conferences, 11 on-site interviews, and 64 other public activities. Additionally, 39 media interviews were arranged during the year, and 462 bilingual press releases were issued. The Authority also handled a large number of media inquiries on a daily basis.

To enhance public understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) key functions, the HKMA organizes press briefings and workshops for local and overseas media, covering a range of topics including the linked exchange rate system, fintech development, green finance, and infrastructure financing. In addition to enriching the content of its existing YouTube channel and LinkedIn page, the HKMA launched an official Facebook page in July, further leveraging social media to strengthen communication with the public.

Mr. Chan Tak-lam, Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (left), and the Environment Bureau's mascot, "Big Waste Ghost," collaborated via social media to promote the use of "Welcome New Notes" for gifting lucky money.

# Public Inquiry

The public inquiry service is an effective channel for enhancing the public's understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's main functions and operations. In 2018, a total of 9,950 inquiries were handled, with about half relating to banking policies and regulations, banking consumer matters, and banknotes and coins, particularly the Coin Collection Scheme, bank products and services, guidelines and notices related to the banking industry, the Fast Payment System "FPS" (TransferFast), virtual banks, and the 2018 Hong Kong New Banknote Series.

# Publication

In addition to the HKMA's Annual Report, the HKMA published two issues of the Semi-Annual Report on Currency and Financial Stability and four issues of the Quarterly Reports in 2018, and regularly updated the data in the Monthly Financial Data Report, providing the latest and thematic information and analysis on Hong Kong's currency, banking, and economic affairs. In addition, the HKMA published a total of 13 Insight articles, elaborating on various thematic issues related to the HKMA's work.

# HKMA Website

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) official website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 60,000 pages of information in English, traditional Chinese, and simplified Chinese, enabling the public to access the latest updates from the HKMA. The website also hosts the "Register of Authorized Institutions and Local Representative Offices," maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, and the "Register of Staff Engaged in Securities Business of Authorized Institutions," as well as the "Register of Licensed Operators of Stored Value Payment Facilities," maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance. The website features dedicated special pages and prominent quick links to alert the public about new HKMA initiatives, such as "FPS" (Fast Payment System), and important timely information, such as warnings against phone scams and the parking locations of cash collection vehicles under the coin collection program.

To promote the banking industry's implementation of open application programming interfaces (APIs), the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has taken the lead by launching open APIs on its website starting in July, making important HKMA information more accessible to the public. The first batch of 50 open API datasets was successfully launched in July, covering areas most frequently accessed by the public, such as statistical data on the banking system and the Exchange Fund, as well as press releases and cash-in-transit schedules. The remaining 80 datasets will be rolled out in phases by mid-2019. To further facilitate public access to the latest news and information about the HKMA on the website, the HKMA is comprehensively revising the website's design and content to make it more user-friendly. The redesigned website is expected to be launched by the end of 2019.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is leading by example in promoting the development and application of open APIs.

# Public Education Program

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of International Finance Centre Phase 2. It introduces the Authority's work and enhances the public's understanding of monetary and banking matters. The Information Centre is divided into two sections: an exhibition hall and a library, which are open to the public six days a week. The exhibition hall introduces the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's work and the development of Hong Kong's monetary and banking sectors. It also provides reading materials and exhibits for research on Hong Kong's currency, banking, and financial affairs.

The Currency Exhibition Area at the Information Centre introduces the design, security features, production processes, and other interesting facts about Hong Kong's banknotes and coins. The exhibition area underwent renovation in the first quarter of 2018, incorporating various interactive elements, such as educational games that combine learning with fun, allowing visitors to gain knowledge about Hong Kong currency while enjoying the experience. Additionally, the exhibition area features an artistic Bauhinia tree composed of 2,018 transparent cubic blocks made from non-circulating, shredded banknotes, complementing another mosaic artwork within the area created using Hong Kong coins. The newly renovated Currency Exhibition Area reopened on August 16.

The Information Center provides guided tours for visitors. This year, the Information Center welcomed over 59,000 visitors and provided guided tours to schools and other groups more than 580 times (Figure 3). Since its commissioning in December 2003, the Information Center has cumulatively welcomed over 705,000 visitors. The library adjacent to the exhibition hall houses over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications for research on topics such as Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central banking. The library also maintains the "Register of Recognized Institutions and Local Representative Offices" and the "Register of Employees Engaged in Securities Business by Recognized Institutions" as required under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Employees

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is part of the government structure but employs staff under non-civil service terms to attract individuals with appropriate experience and specialized expertise. As a public institution, the HKMA continuously streamlines its work processes to enhance efficiency and cost-effectiveness. The HKMA is committed to maintaining a lean and flexible organizational structure, and wherever possible, it implements new initiatives and manages increasing workloads by redeploying its existing staff.

The HKMA is an employer that provides equal employment opportunities and ensures that employees can work in a discrimination-free environment. The HKMA's equal opportunities policy applies to areas such as hiring, compensation and benefits, performance evaluations, promotions, transfers/training opportunities, and general conduct.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) employs, trains, and maintains a professional and competent workforce to fulfill its policy objectives and flexibly respond to changes in work requirements. The HKMA requires its staff to uphold high standards of integrity and morality, adhering at all times to the highest standards of personal conduct and ethical guidelines, and acting in the best interests of the HKMA.

The Foreign Exchange Fund Investment Office was established on August 1, replacing the investment and related risk management functions previously handled by the Reserve Management Department and the Risk Management and Supervision Department. The establishment of the Foreign Exchange Fund Investment Office highlights the Monetary Authority's investment functions, enhances its institutional image, and enables a more flexible response to market changes, supporting the ongoing expansion and diversification of the Fund's investment activities.

# Compensation and Benefits Policy and Compensation Review Mechanism

The Chief of the Financial Services Department determines the salaries and service conditions of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) employees by consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee on the opinions of its governing committees, and by referring to market salary levels and practices. The compensation package includes cash salary and a pension fund, along with some basic benefits. The cash salary comprises a monthly fixed salary (i.e., base salary) and an annual variable salary paid once a year based on employee performance.

The Chief of the Financial Services Department reviews the salaries of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) staff annually by consulting the recommendations of the Governance Committee through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and takes into account the Governance Committee's assessment of the HKMA's performance over the past year, the results of salary surveys conducted by an independent human resources consultancy in the financial sector, as well as other relevant factors. Salaries of individual employees with outstanding performance may also be subject to special adjustments to maintain their competitiveness.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) allocates approved funds for adjusting annual fixed and variable pay based on individual employees' performance. The variable pay system applicable to investment staff is designed to strengthen the link between their investment performance and compensation. For employees at or above the level of Deputy Governor, adjustments to fixed pay and distribution of variable pay are approved by the Chief Secretary for Finance after consulting the Governance Committee. Such employees are excused from attending meetings where their pay matters are discussed. For employees at or below the level of Director, adjustments to fixed pay and distribution of variable pay are determined by the HKMA Governor, based on authorization from the Chief Secretary for Finance and in accordance with the approved lump sum allocated for salary payments.

就財務報表審計而言，我有責任閱讀其他資料，從而考慮其他資料是否與財務報表或我在審計過程中得悉的情況有重大矛盾，或者似乎存有重大錯誤陳述。基於我已執行的工作，如果我認為其他資料存有重大錯誤陳述，我需要報告該事實。在這方面，我沒有任何報告。

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：

- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to Notes 2.5, 2.6, and 40.1 of the financial statements.

As of December 31, 2018, the Group's financial assets accounted for at fair value totaled 3,693.589 billion Hong Kong dollars, and financial liabilities totaled 1,133.829 billion Hong Kong dollars.

Given the large amounts involved and the use of estimates, the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value is a key audit matter.

The audit procedures for the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value include:

- Understand the valuation procedures for different categories of financial assets and liabilities, including relevant monitoring measures;
- Evaluate and test monitoring measures, including those related to application programs in computer systems;
- Obtain confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and liabilities;
- If market quotes are used, verify the prices against independent sources;
- If the parameters used in the valuation method are based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation method is appropriate and whether the related assumptions are reasonable, and verify the parameters against independent sources; and
- If the parameters used in the valuation method are not based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation method is appropriate, and whether the related assumptions and parameters are reasonable.

# Valuation of Investment Properties Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to Notes 2.12, 20, and 21 to the financial statements.

- Assess the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and
- Evaluate whether the valuation methods are appropriate and whether the related assumptions and parameters are reasonable.

# The Responsibilities of Auditors in the Audit of Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance regarding whether the financial statements as a whole contain no material misstatements resulting from fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it does not guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with audit standards will necessarily detect all material misstatements. A misstatement is considered material if it is reasonably expected that it, individually or in aggregate, could influence the economic decisions made by users of the financial statements.

During the audit process conducted in accordance with the Audit Office's audit standards, I will exercise professional judgment and maintain a professional skepticism. I will also:

- Identify and assess the risk of material misstatements in the financial statements resulting from fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. - Determine whether the Financial Management Officer's use of the going concern basis of accounting is appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are material uncertainties related to events or circumstances that may cast significant doubt on the Group's ability to continue as a going concern. - Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements fairly reflect the transactions and events;
- Obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and performing the Group audit. I take full responsibility for my audit opinion.
